scenesList.scene_7: Park High's Hit Distribution Analysis Conclusion
scenesList.scene_9: Park High's Pitching Performance Analytics Conclusion
scenesList.scene_11: Park High's Season Performance Analysis Conclusion

start.title:
Baseball Analytics: A Game Plan for Victory
Taking Baseball Analytics from Dot Plots to Big Wins
start.description: Can you help Park High's team strategize for the championship? In this STEAMQuest, you will use dot plots, box plots and histograms to analyze batting, scoring, and pitching. Your data-driven insights could lead the team to triumph!

S2.S2_D1_F3_C0:
Welcome to Park High's Dugout Strategy Session!

Iâ€™m Coach Martinez. We've got one shot at the championship, and every decision counts. Today, Jamie, our data analyst and I are digging into our stats to fine-tune the lineup, spot weaknesses, and give our team the edge.

S3.S3_D1_F4_C1: Something's not clicking with our team lately...
S3.S3_D2_F5_C2: Got a minute, Coach? I wanted to talk about our upcoming championship game.
S3.S3_D3_F6_C1: Jamie! Perfect timing. I was just thinking about our recent games, and somethingâ€™s not sitting right.
S3.S3_D4_F7_C2: I've noticed it too. The team's energy isn't the same as it was at the start of the season.
S3.S3_D5_F8_C1: We've got talented players, good practice sessions, but when game time comes, it just doesn't show.
S3.S3_D6_F9_C2: Yeah, I've been thinking the same thing. Let me show you something real quick.

S4_D0_F10_C9.title: Park High's Recent Performance Summary
S4_D0_F10_C9.aria_label: Table showing baseball team statistics for the last 5 games including hits, runs, errors, and pitch count

S4.S4_D1_F10_C2: Actually, Coach, Iâ€™ve been tracking our hits, runs, and pitch counts for the whole season. And the last five? The numbers tell a different story.
S4.S4_D2_F11_C1: Wait a second... you're saying weâ€™ve dropped to an average of 7.8 hits per game?
S4.S4_D3_F12_C2: Exactly. And itâ€™s not just hits, our runs per game have fallen from 6.2 to just 2.8.
S4.S4_D4_F13_C1: No wonder I was feeling that something was wrong. The hits and runs from the last five games are way below our season averages.
S4.S4_D5_F14_C2: And notice the pitch counts, Coach. They're creeping up. Our pitchers are working harder for each out.
S4.S4_D6_F15_C1: Alright, Jamie. You've got my full attention. What do you think we should look at first?

S5.S5_D1_F16_C2: Let's take a look at our team's recent performance. I've been tracking our number of hits using something called a dot plot. Each dot represents that particular game's hits.
S5.S5_D2_F17_C1: And how does this help us see patterns?

aria_label.title: Park High's Hit Distribution Analysis
aria_label.game24_button: Select number of hits for Game 24
aria_label.game25_button: Select number of hits for Game 25

about.body:
• A dot plot helps visualize the distribution of hits. Each dot represents one game.
  • Each number along the number line shows the number of hits.
  • Stacked dots indicate multiple games with the same number of hits.
  • The median (middle value) is shown with a dashed line.

help.heading: Using the Analyzer
help.body:
1. Viewing Current Data
  • Each dot represents one game
  • Each number along the number line shows number of hits
  • Stacked dots indicate multiple games with the same number of hits
2. Adding New Data
  • Select the number of hits for Game 24
  • Select the number of hits for Game 25
3. Reading the Plot
  • Hover over dots to see more information about the game
  • Note how new dots affect median of the distribution

S6.S6_D1_F18_C2: See how the dots spread from 7 hits to 16 hits along the bottom? When we have multiple games with the same number of hits, the dots stack up vertically. That dashed line in the middle shows our median - where half our games had more hits and half had fewer.
S6.S6_D2_F19_C1: Oh I see! Because 13 has three dots, that means there were 3 games that had 13 hits.
S6.S6_D3_F20_C2: Yep! The hits are spread out, with no strong cluster around any number.
S6.S6_D4_F21_C2: Looking at our past 23 games, you can hover over any dot to see whether the number of hits in that game are below the median, equal to the median or above the median.
S6.S6_D5_F22_C1: Okay, I'm able to see the information for each dot on the plot!
S6.S6_D6_F23_C2: Now let's add new dots for the upcoming games, Select 10 hits for game 24 and 14 hits for game 25.
S6.S6_D7_F24_C2: With these new values that we are inserting, what's our new median value for hitting?
S6.S6_D8_F25_C1: I see the median is still 12. Because we have new values at each side of the median. So, there shouldn't be any change.
S6.S6_D9_F26_C2: Right! With our new data points, our median stays the same.
S6.S6_D10_F27_C2: Now let's try with some different values for both new games. Select 8 hits for game 24 and 10 hits for game 25.
S6.S6_D11_F28_C2: What's our new median value for hitting?
S6.S6_D12_F29_C1: It's now 11. Since we have added games having lower number of hits than our original median, it pulled the median down.
S6.S6_D13_F30_C2: Exactly. When we add values lower than the median, the median shifts towards the left.
S6.S6_D14_F31_C1: To prevent our median from going down, we need to aim for at least 12 hits in either game 24 or game 25.
S6.S6_D15_F32_C2: Yes, that way at least we stay consistent and don't let low-hit games pull our performance down.

S7.S7_D1_F33_C2: Now let's analyze our pitchers using box plots. Box plots are perfect for comparing player performances.
S7.S7_D2_F34_C1: Box plots? Sounds fancy, walk me through it.

S8_D0_F35_C9.title: Park High's Pitching Performance Analytics
S8_D0_F35_C9.help_box:
• Box Components
    • Middle line = Median
    • Box edges = Q1 and Q3
    • Whiskers = Range
  • Comparison Tools
    • Compare box sizes for consistency
    • Compare medians for performance
  • Making Decisions
    • Larger boxes indicate more variable performance
    • Higher median indicates better typical performance
S8_D0_F35_C9.info_box:
Box plots provide a summary of the distribution of the number of strikes per game for each player:

  • Median shows typical performance
  • Box shows middle 50% of data
  • Whiskers show overall range

This visualization helps compare:

  • Performance levels
  • Consistency
  • Best/worst outings
S8_D0_F35_C9.subtitle: Single Game Strike Distribution (Current Season)
S8_D0_F35_C9.aria_label: Box plot visualization of baseball pitchers' strike distributions

understanding_box.title: Understanding the Numbers:
understanding_box.1: Starting pitchers typically throw 5-7 innings, resulting in 30-65 strikes per game
understanding_box.2: "All Pitchers" shows the combined distribution for the entire rotation

S8.S8_D1_F35_C2: Think of it as a summary of all their performances. The box shows where 50% of their performances fall, with a line in the middle showing the median. The whiskers show the full range.
S8.S8_D2_F36_C1: Oh! I see. Here the prominent part is the box, any reason why we are focusing on that area?
S8.S8_D3_F37_C2: Yes coach! It's called an IQR - Interquartile Range., This is the middle 50% of the data, from the 25th percentile (quartile 1) to the 75th percentile (quartile 3). It tells us where the middle 50% of the performances lie.
S8.S8_D4_F38_C2: Which player has the highest maximum strike count amongst all players?
S8.S8_D5_F39_C2: Correct, Ethan has the highest maximum strike count amongst all three players.
S8.S8_D6_F40_C1: Does that mean Ethan is performing best amongst all players?
S8.S8_D7_F41_C2: No, we need to see who's more consistent. See the boxes?
S8.S8_D8_F42_C2: A larger box means more variable performance, while a smaller box shows consistency.
S8.S8_D9_F43_C2: Who shows the most consistent performance?
S8.S8_D10_F44_C2: Correct! Lucas's smaller box shows he's more consistent than Ethan, even though Ethan occasionally hits those higher strike counts.
S8.S8_D11_F45_C1: That reliability could be crucial in a championship game. That's an excellent insight to have.

S9.S9_D1_F46_C1: Great! Now, I'd like to analyze all the games and how much we scored by game. Can we use dot plots for that? It'll give us a better overview of the data.
S9.S9_D2_F47_C2: Coach, with 35+ games, a dot plot would be a little too crowded. Histograms work better hereâ€”they group similar results and give a clearer picture of the season.
S9.S9_D3_F48_C1: How's this different from our dot plot?
S9.S9_D4_F49_C2: Instead of individual dots, histogram bars show how many games we had within each scoring range. The height of each bar shows frequency - how often we scored that many runs.
S9.S9_D5_F50_C1: And is it also possible to compare the games between our team and the rival team?
S9.S9_D6_F51_C2: Absolutely coach, that's really convenient with histograms.

S10_D0_F52_C9.title: Park High's Season Performance Analysis
S10_D0_F52_C9.aria_label: Statistical comparison of scoring distributions between Park High and Eagles teams

tooltips.mean_formula_our_team:
Mean Calculation for Our Team:
Formula: Mean = Sum of ( x Ã— frequency ) / total games
where: x = bin center
Example calculation:
Sum of ( bin center Ã— frequency ):
2.5 Ã— 1 games +
4.5 Ã— 8 games +
6.5 Ã— 17 games +
8.5 Ã— 6 games +
10.5 Ã— 2 games +
12.5 Ã— 1 games +
14.5 Ã— 0 games
Divided by 35 total games = 6.67
tooltips.std_dev_formula_our_team:
Standard Deviation for Our Team:
Formula: Standard Deviation = âˆš( Sum of ( ( x − Mean ) Â² Ã— frequency ) / total games )
Where:
x = bin center
Mean = 6.67
Steps:
1. Calculate ( x − Mean ) Â² for each bin
2. Multiply by frequency
3. Sum all values
4. Divide by total games (35)
5. Take the square root
Result: 1.99
tooltips.mean_formula_eagles:
Mean Calculation for Eagles:
Formula: Mean = Sum of ( x Ã— frequency ) / total games
where: x = bin center
Example calculation:
Sum of ( bin center Ã— frequency ):
2.5 Ã— 4 games +
4.5 Ã— 7 games +
6.5 Ã— 9 games +
8.5 Ã— 8 games +
10.5 Ã— 5 games +
12.5 Ã— 2 games +
14.5 Ã— 1 games
Divided by 36 total games = 7.22
tooltips.std_dev_formula_eagles:
Standard Deviation for Eagles:
Formula: Standard Deviation = âˆš( Sum of ( ( x − Mean ) Â² Ã— frequency ) / total games )
Where:
x = bin center
Mean = 7.22
Steps:
1. Calculate ( x − Mean ) Â² for each bin
2. Multiply by frequency
3. Sum all values
4. Divide by total games (36)
5. Take the square root
Result: 2.99

chart.histogram_prefix: Histogram showing distribution of runs per game for

aria.tooltip_navigation: Use arrow keys to navigate between bars

about.body:
Histograms are ideal for large datasets, showing:
  • Frequency of different run totals
  • Overall scoring patterns
  • Team scoring consistency
Key Statistics:
  • Mean runs per game
  • Standard deviation (spread)
This helps identify scoring tendencies and compare team performances effectively.

help.heading: Reading the Histogram
help.body:
1. Bar Heights
  • Show frequency of run totals
  • Taller bars indicate more common scores
2. Analysis Tools
  • Mean shows average runs
  • Standard deviation shows consistency

S10.S10_D1_F52_C2: Let's compare our run distribution with the rival team Eagles.
S10.S10_D2_F53_C2: Which team has a higher average number of runs per game?
S10.S10_D3_F54_C2: Correct, now notice the spread... That's where the standard deviation comes inâ€”it shows us how consistent the teams are. A lower standard deviation means a more consistent performance.
S10.S10_D4_F55_C2: Looking at both distributions, which team seems more consistent?
S10.S10_D5_F56_C2: Well observed! Our team's standard deviation is lower compared to the Eagles. That means our scoring is more predictable.
S10.S10_D6_F57_C1: So we might have fewer high-scoring games than the Eagles, but we're less likely to have really low-scoring games too?
S10.S10_D7_F58_C2: That's exactly right, Coach! This consistency could be a real advantage in the championships where every run counts.

S11.S11_D1_F59_C2: Now for our pitching rotation decision, we have an interesting comparison between two of our fastest pitchers, Steve and Sam.
S11.S11_D2_F60_C1: I would say, we really needed this discussion. What have you got here, Jamie?

S12_D0_F60_C9.title: Park High's Pitching Speed Distribution
S12_D0_F60_C9.aria_label: Comparison of fastball speeds between two pitchers

stats.mean_formula: Formula: Mean = Sum of(speed Ã— frequency) / total pitches
stats.median_formula: Formula: The middle value when all pitches are arranged in order

sort_values.steve: Sort all 100 pitch speeds in ascending order
sort_values.sam: Sort all 100 pitch speeds in ascending order

average_middle_values.steve: Since there are an even number of pitches, take the average of two middle values: (92.5 + 92.5)/2 = 92.5
average_middle_values.sam: Since there are an even number of pitches, take the average of two middle values: (86.5 + 86.5)/2 = 86.5

mean_formula.steve:
Mean formula for Steve's pitches

Sum of (speed Ã— count) Ã· total pitches
mean_formula.sam:
Mean formula for Sam's pitches

Sum of (speed Ã— count) Ã· total pitches

std_dev_formula.steve:
Median calculation for Steve's pitches

Middle value when all pitches are arranged in order
std_dev_formula.sam:
Median calculation for Sam's pitches

Middle value when all pitches are arranged in order

about.heading: Player Pitching Speed Distribution
about.body:
Steveâ€™s Performance: Follows a normal distribution where pitch speeds are symmetrically clustered around the mean.
Samâ€™s Performance: Shows a right-skewed distribution, where most pitches are on the slower side, with a few extremely fast pitches raising the average.
Key Metrics:
  • Pitching Speed (mph): Measures how fast a player throws.
  • Mean: The mean represents the average speed of all pitches. It gives an overall idea of performance but can be influenced by outliers, like a few very fast pitches.
  • Median: The median is the middle value when all pitch speeds are arranged in order. It is less affected by extremes and gives a clearer picture of typical performance.
This comparison helps evaluate which pitcher delivers consistent, reliable speed versus who occasionally throws very fast but lacks consistency.

help.heading: Using the Analysis Tool
help.body:
• Graph Elements:
    • Bars: Represent Steve's and Samâ€™s pitching speeds across 100 fastballs
    • Horizontal Axis: Pitching speed (mph)
    • Vertical Axis: Number of pitches
  • Pattern Recognition:
    • Tall Bars (Steve):
      • Consistent pitching speeds with minimal variation
      • Reflects a normal distribution where most values are tightly clustered around the mean in a bell shape
    • Wider Spread and Skewed Bars (Sam):
      • Shows a right-skewed distribution, with most pitches concentrated between 80â€“85 mph
      • A few pitches in the 90â€“101 mph range pull the mean up to 86.6 mph, but the median remains lower at 84.5 mph
      • Indicates high variability, as Sam's pitching speeds cover a much wider range, showing both slow and extremely fast pitches rather than consistent performance
  • Making Comparisons:
    • Distribution Shape:
      • Normal Distribution (Symmetrical): Reflects steady and reliable performance. Steve's speeds are centered and consistent around 86â€“87 mph
      • Right-Skewed Distribution: Indicates inconsistency. Sam's distribution has most pitches in the lower speed ranges and only a few very fast pitches raising the average

S12.S12_D1_F60_C2: Coach, here are histograms of both pitchers' fastball speeds over their last 100 pitches. This should help us decide who's better suited for the next big game.
S12.S12_D2_F61_C2: Looking at the stats, who has a higher average pitching speed?
S12.S12_D3_F62_C1: Sam has a higher mean pitching speed at 86.6 mph compared to Steve's 86.5 mph. So maybe Sam throws faster than Steve?
S12.S12_D4_F63_C2: Wait, it's not that simple. A higher mean doesn't always tell the full story. If you look closely at Sam's distribution, it's right skewed. That means a few really fast pitches are pulling up the average, but most of his pitches were actually slower.
S12.S12_D5_F64_C1: Oh I see. Then is there another statistical measure we can use?
S12.S12_D6_F65_C2: Yes, Coach. We should look at the median. It shows the middle value of all pitches and isn't affected much by outliers like those rare blazing fastballs.
S12.S12_D7_F66_C2: Now looking at the median, who do you think is consistently throwing fast pitches?
S12.S12_D8_F67_C2: Correct! Sam's median is 84.5 mph, which is lower than his mean and Steve's median is 86.5 mph, the same as his mean.
S12.S12_D9_F68_C2: That tells us Steve is consistently throwing fast pitches, while Sam had a few really fast ones but usually threw slower than his average.
S12.S12_D10_F69_C1: That makes sense. What about consistency?
S12.S12_D11_F70_C2: We can judge consistency by seeing how closely the pitches group around the median. Steve's speeds form a tight, bell-shaped pattern, showing he's reliable. Sam's are more spread out, with highs and lows.
S12.S12_D12_F71_C1: So Steve's median being higher than his mean, and his distribution being more clustered near the center, shows he's the more consistent performer.
S12.S12_D13_F72_C2: Exactly. Sam may hit higher speeds at times, but Steve is the one you can count on every pitch.
S12.S12_D14_F73_C1: Alright, let's go with Steve for the next start. Consistency wins games.

S13.S13_D1_F74_C2: You know Coach, it's amazing how different statistical tools can reveal different stories about the game.
S13.S13_D2_F75_C1: You've really opened my eyes today. Each type of graph showed us something unique.
S13.S13_D3_F76_C2:
Exactly! Like how:
  • â€¢ Dot plots helped us spot recent performance trends
  • â€¢ Box plots showed us pitcher consistency
  • â€¢ Histograms let us compare large sets of data
  • â€¢ Distribution patterns revealed the true story behind higher mean pitching speeds
S13.S13_D4_F77_C1: And each tool helped us make a different kind of decision. Data isn't just numbers - it is a tool for understanding the game better.
S13.S13_D5_F78_C2: That's what makes baseball analytics so powerful. It combines America's favorite pastime with the power of statistical analysis!

quest_completion.subheading: You have now explored the analysis of Park High's baseball games using statistics
quest_completion.content:
You've completed the Baseball Analytics: A Game Plan for Victory STEAMQuest!

  • â€¢You used dot plots to represent the number of hits the team has achieved in past 25 games
  • â€¢You compared batting performance of two teams using histograms and used standard deviation to analyze consistency
  • â€¢You compared strike values of pitchers using box plots
  • â€¢You used histograms to compare pitching speeds of two players and explored how median helps in making informed decisions when the distribution is skewed

Your analysis will help lead Park High's team to victory with data-driven decisions! âš¾ ðŸ“Š

dot_plot.definition: A Dot Plot is a type of graph that shows individual data points along a number line.

dot_plots.definition: A Dot Plot is a type of graph that shows individual data points along a number line.

histogram.definition: A Histogram is a graphical representation that groups data into ranges and displays frequencies using bars.

histograms.definition: A Histogram is a graphical representation that groups data into ranges and displays frequencies using bars.

box_plot.definition: A Box Plot is a visual summary of data showing the minimum, maximum, and median values, and the first and third quartile.

box_plots.definition: A Box Plot is a visual summary of data showing the minimum, maximum, and median values, and the first and third quartile.

strike.definition: Strike is a pitched ball that the batter either swings at and misses, or doesn't swing at but is within the strike zone.

strikes.definition: Strike is a pitched ball that the batter either swings at and misses, or doesn't swing at but is within the strike zone.

strike_rate.definition: Strike Rate is the percentage of pitches a pitcher successfully throws for strikes.

strike_rates.definition: Strike Rate is the percentage of pitches a pitcher successfully throws for strikes.

iqr.definition: InterQuartile Range is the difference of the third and first quartiles and represents the spread of the middle 50% of the data values.

normal_distribution.definition: Normal Distribution is a distribution where data values are symmetrically distributed around the mean and forms a bell-shaped curve.

median.definition: Median is a middle value in a data set when arranged in order.

outliers.definition: Outlier is a data point significantly different from the others in the data set.

standard_deviation.definition: Standard Deviation is a measure that shows how data vary, or deviate, from the mean.

right_skewed.definition: Right Skewed has most of its values on the left, with a long tail stretching to the right due to a few larger values.

percentile.definition: A Percentile is the percentage of values less than or equal to a particular data value.

common.jamie_description: Jamie Solomon: Inquisitive Data Analyst, merging baseball and analytics with sharp insights.
common.martinez_description: Coach Marcus Martinez: Seasoned Baseball Coach, blending discipline, strategy, and motivation.
common.bg1_description: Modern campus building entrance with students walking on landscaped pathways.
common.bg2_description: Office workspace with digital displays, bulletin board, and plants in blue theme.
common.bg3_description: Empty computer classroom with blue monitors and large projection screen.
common.bg4_description: Baseball field with stadium seating, dugout, and players practicing.

game.baseball-game-plan: STEAM Quest - Baseball by the Numbers
